author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.en: Numbered Discourses 8
2. The Great Chapter
14. A Wild Colt

segments.pli: “Aṭṭha ca, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅke desessāmi aṭṭha ca assadose, aṭṭha ca purisakhaḷuṅke aṭṭha ca purisadose.
segments.en: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight wild colts and eight defects in horses, and about eight wild people and eight defects in people.

segments.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Katame ca, bhikkhave, aṭṭha assakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca assadosā?
segments.en: “And what, mendicants, are the eight wild colts and eight defects in horses?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchato paṭikkamati, piṭṭhito rathaṃ pavatteti.
segments.en: Firstly, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the first defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchā laṅghati, kubbaraṃ hanati, tidaṇḍaṃ bhañjati.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the second defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā rathīsāya satthiṃ ussajjitvā rathīsaṃyeva ajjhomaddati.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the third defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā ummaggaṃ gaṇhati, ubbaṭumaṃ rathaṃ karoti.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the fourth defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā laṅghati purimakāyaṃ paggaṇhati purime pāde.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the fifth defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā anādiyitvā sārathiṃ anādiyitvā patodalaṭṭhiṃ dantehi mukhādhānaṃ vidhaṃsitvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the sixth defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā neva abhikkamati no paṭikkamati tattheva khīlaṭṭhāyī ṭhito hoti.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the seventh defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā purime ca pāde saṃharitvā pacchime ca pāde saṃharitvā tattheva cattāro pāde abhinisīdati.
segments.en: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
Some wild colts are like that.
This is the eighth defect of a horse.

segments.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha assakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca assadosā.
segments.en: These are the eight wild colts and the eight defects in horses.

segments.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, aṭṭha purisakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca purisadosā?
segments.en: And what are the eight wild people and eight defects in people?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Firstly, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno ‘na sarāmī’ti asatiyā nibbeṭheti.
segments.en: But the accused mendicant evades it by saying they don’t remember.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchato paṭikkamati, piṭṭhito rathaṃ vatteti;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, back right up and spin the chariot behind them.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the first defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno codakaṃyeva paṭippharati:
segments.en: But the accused mendicant objects to the accuser:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tuyhaṃ bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena.
segments.en: ‘What has an incompetent fool like you got to say?
How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchā laṅghati, kubbaraṃ hanati, tidaṇḍaṃ bhañjati;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the second defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno codakasseva paccāropeti:
segments.en: But the accused mendicant retorts to the accuser:

segments.pli: ‘tvaṃ khosi itthannāmaṃ āpattiṃ āpanno, tvaṃ tāva paṭhamaṃ paṭikarohī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Well, you’ve fallen into such-and-such an offense. You should deal with that first.’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā rathīsāya satthiṃ ussajjitvā rathīsaṃyeva ajjhomaddati;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the third defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno aññenāññaṃ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
segments.en: But the accused mendicant dodges the issue, distracts the discussion with irrelevant points, and displays annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā ummaggaṃ gaṇhati, ubbaṭumaṃ rathaṃ karoti;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the fourth defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno saṅghamajjhe bāhuvikkhepaṃ karoti.
segments.en: But the accused mendicant gesticulates while speaking in the middle of the Saṅgha.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā laṅghati, purimakāyaṃ paggaṇhati purime pāde;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the fifth defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno anādiyitvā saṅghaṃ anādiyitvā codakaṃ sāpattikova yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
segments.en: But the accused mendicant ignores the Saṅgha and the accusation and, though still guilty of the offense, they go wherever they want.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā anādiyitvā sārathiṃ anādiyitvā patodalaṭṭhiṃ dantehi mukhādhānaṃ vidhaṃsitvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the sixth defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno ‘nevāhaṃ āpannomhi, na panāhaṃ āpannomhī’ti so tuṇhībhāvena saṃghaṃ viheṭheti.
segments.en: But the accused mendicant neither confesses to the offense nor denies it, but frustrates the Saṅgha by staying silent.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā neva abhikkamati no paṭikkamati tattheva khīlaṭṭhāyī ṭhito hoti;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the seventh defect of a person.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
segments.en: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

segments.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno evamāha:
segments.en: But the accused mendicant says this:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tumhe āyasmanto atibāḷhaṃ mayi byāvaṭā yāva idānāhaṃ sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Why are you venerables making so much of an issue over me? Now I’ll reject the training and return to a lesser life.’
When they have rejected the training, they say:
‘Well, venerables, are you happy now?’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā purime ca pāde saṃharitvā pacchime ca pāde saṃharitvā tattheva cattāro pāde abhinisīdati;
segments.en: I say that this person is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.
Some wild people are like that.
This is the eighth defect of a person.

segments.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha purisakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca purisadosā”ti.
segments.en: These are the eight wild people and eight defects in people.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight wild colts…

suttaplex.blurb: Eight flaws in wild horses, similar to eight flaws in mendicants.
